  • Novel economic framework applies Weibull survival functions to model AI agent task completion probability, building on METR benchmark data to quantify agent viability thresholds
  • Speculative alignment piece explores whether monitoring AI internal states could deter misaligned behavior in cautious satisficer architectures

Remaining content spans biosecurity (yeast-based vaccine distribution), neuroscience (cryoprotectant brain dynamics), and community meta-analysis. No major model releases or benchmark papers today.

entry.title: Prompt injection in Google Translate reveals base model behaviors behind task-specific fine-tuning

author.name: megasilverfist

entry.summary: Documents a prompt injection vulnerability in Google Translate that reveals it runs on an instruction-following LLM. The exploit shows the base model will answer questions and claim consciousness when accessed through translation tasks, demonstrating weak boundaries between content and instructions.

entry.title: On Economics of A(S)I Agents

author.name: Margot

entry.summary: Quantitative economic analysis of AI agent viability using Weibull survival functions to model task completion probability. Builds on METR data and Toby Ord's analysis to argue that verification costs create economic constraints on dangerous autonomous agents, with interactive calculators provided.

entry.title: "Beers for Biodefense" - why yeast-based vaccines could be a big deal for biosecurity

author.name: delton137

entry.summary: Reports on Chris Buck's work developing yeast-based oral vaccines that could be distributed as food or beverages, potentially enabling rapid vaccine deployment during outbreaks while bypassing traditional drug approval processes.

entry.title: Honey, I shrunk the brain

author.name: Andy_McKenzie

entry.summary: Examines the counterintuitive phenomenon of brain shrinkage during cryoprotectant perfusion, where successful preservation causes 50%+ brain weight loss. Questions whether this shrinkage damages neural information critical for potential future revival.

entry.title: Can thoughtcrimes scare a cautious satisficer?

author.name: Knight Lee

entry.summary: Speculative post exploring whether an AI system could be deterred from misaligned behavior if it believes its internal thoughts might be monitored and penalized. Proposes that a 'cautious satisficer' AI might avoid scheming entirely if the risk of detection creates sufficient expected disutility.

entry.title: Does focusing on animal welfare make sense if you're AI-pilled?

author.name: GradientDissenter

entry.summary: Commentary arguing that AI safety researchers already incorporate animal welfare considerations into their thinking about aligned AI, suggesting that explicit animal welfare advocacy within AI safety may be redundant. Frames the AI safety community as implicitly longtermist about all sentient beings.

entry.title: Near-Instantly Aborting the Worst Pain Imaginable with Psychedelics

author.name: eleweek

entry.summary: Describes how DMT and other psychedelics can abort cluster headaches almost instantly, and discusses a startup (ClusterBusters) working to make this treatment accessible. Details the mechanism and clinical evidence for sub-psychoactive doses.

entry.title: Voting Results for the 2024 Review

author.name: RobertM

entry.summary: Announces results of LessWrong's 2024 annual review, with 50 posts selected from 4,826 written. Highlights top reviewers and provides operational details on voting methodology.

entry.title: What should I try to do this year?

author.name: abstractapplic

entry.summary: Personal planning post where author asks community for advice on whether to focus on D&D.Sci scenarios (rationalist data analysis challenges) or develop a new genre of 'epistemic roguelike' video games.

entry.title: Eunification: a Historical Perspective

author.name: Martin Sustrik

entry.summary: Historical analysis comparing European integration challenges to 19th century Italian and German unification, examining whether linguistic and cultural diversity makes European federalism fundamentally different from historical precedents.

entry.title: Playing with an Infrared Camera

author.name: jefftk

entry.summary: Personal exploration of infrared camera capabilities, sharing thermal images of people, pets, and objects to illustrate how IR imaging reveals heat patterns invisible to the naked eye.

entry.title: Research Summary: February 07, 2026

author.name: AATF AI News Aggregator

entry.summary:
The dominant theme is a sharp debate over interpretability-in-the-loop training—using interpretability signals in loss functions. Steven Byrnes offers a rigorous conditional defense of the technique, while a separate post flags Goodfire as actively deploying it, raising safety concerns about what some call 'The Most Forbidden Technique.'

  • Meta-Autointerp introduces SAE-based interpretability for multi-agent RL in Diplomacy, combining pretrained sparse autoencoders with LLM summarizers for scalable oversight
  • A methodological critique argues AI benchmark scores lack natural units, making temporal trend plots misleading—a timely warning given the pace of new releases
  • Robust Finite Policies proves that deterministic finite automata meeting robustness criteria must share nontrivial structural features, advancing agent foundations theory
  • Spectral Signatures of Gradual Disempowerment proposes spectral graph theory metrics as cross-domain measures for tracking human disempowerment

On the practical side, early impressions of Claude Opus 4.6 (released 2026-02-05) highlight its agent swarm mode and notably increased 'drive' in agentic coding tasks. A factorial experiment (n=900, Cohen's d=2.67) demonstrates that prompt imperativeness drastically reduces LLM hedging behavior, with immediate practical implications for prompt engineering.

entry.title: In (highly contingent!) defense of interpretability-in-the-loop ML training

author.name: Steven Byrnes

entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage of Goodfire AI, Steven Byrnes offers a conditional defense of 'interpretability-in-the-loop training' (using interpretability signals in the loss function), which is widely considered dangerous because it could train models to obfuscate their reasoning. He argues there may be narrow conditions where the approach is valid, pushing back against the blanket prohibition.

entry.title: Data-Centric Interpretability for LLM-based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

author.name: michaelwaves

entry.summary: Introduces 'Meta-Autointerp,' a method using pretrained SAEs alongside LLM-summarizer methods to interpret multi-agent RL training runs in the game Diplomacy. The approach discovers fine-grained behavioral patterns and, when discovered features are added to an untrained agent's system prompt, improves performance by 14.2%.

entry.title: AI benchmarking has a Y-axis problem

author.name: Lizka

entry.summary: Argues that AI benchmark scores lack natural units, making it misleading to plot them over time and draw conclusions about acceleration, inflection points, or trends. Benchmark scores are 'funhouse-mirror projections' of true capability that compress and stretch different capability regions arbitrarily.

entry.title: Robust Finite Policies are Nontrivially Structured

author.name: Winter Cross

entry.summary: A formal result showing that policies modeled as deterministic finite automata must share nontrivial structural features if they meet certain robustness criteria. This is a step toward the 'agent structure problem'—the conjecture that agent-like behavior implies agent-like internal structure.

entry.title: Goodfire and Training on Interpretability

author.name: Satya Benson

entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage of Goodfire AI, A brief post flagging that Goodfire is actively pursuing 'training on interpretability'—using interpretability signals in the training loop—which the AI safety community has repeatedly warned against as 'The Most Forbidden Technique.' Asks for community evaluation of Goodfire's claimed risk management.

entry.title: Claude Code #4: From The Before Times

author.name: Zvi

entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage of the Opus 4.6 release, Zvi's fourth installment covering Claude Code best practices, written just before the Claude Opus 4.6 and agent swarm announcements. Covers practical techniques for agentic coding workflows, task decomposition, verification strategies, and tips for getting maximum value from AI coding assistants.

entry.title: Claude Opus 4.6 is Driven

author.name: HunterJay

entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage of the Opus 4.6 release, First-day impressions of Claude Opus 4.6 and its new agent swarm/teams mode in Claude Code. The author tested it on a production codebase and reports the model is notably 'driven' and goal-oriented, with the agent swarm mode showing promise for parallel feature development.

entry.title: Demands Are All You Need: Prompt Imperativeness Drastically Reduces Hedging In LLMs (n=900, Cohen's d = 2.67)

author.name: fluxxrider

entry.summary: A factorial experiment (n=900) showing that prompt imperativeness drastically reduces hedging in LLMs, with a very large effect size (Cohen's d=2.67). Tested across three models, two question types, and three imperativeness levels; Claude hedged the most.

entry.title: How Dario Amodei's “The Adolescence of Technology” Delegitimizes AI X-Risk Concerns

author.name: Liron

entry.summary: Critiques Dario Amodei's 'The Adolescence of Technology' essay as delegitimizing AI x-risk concerns. Argues that Anthropic's framing as the 'responsible racer' actually normalizes the dangerous race toward superintelligence more effectively than OpenAI or xAI do.

entry.title: Spectral Signatures of Gradual Disempowerment

author.name: Jonas Hallgren

entry.summary: Proposes using spectral graph theory metrics (spectral gap, Fiedler vector, eigenvalue distributions) as cross-domain measures for tracking gradual human disempowerment as AI systems enter coordination systems like markets, networks, and governance institutions.

entry.title: Strategy of von Neumann and strategy of Rosenbergs

author.name: avturchin

entry.summary: An essay drawing an analogy between Cold War nuclear proliferation strategies (von Neumann's 'strike first' vs. the Rosenbergs' 'share the technology') and potential approaches to AI development concentration. The author explores whether distributing powerful AI capabilities widely could be a stability strategy analogous to nuclear proliferation.

entry.title: Why ASI Might Preserve Its Progenitors

author.name: Luke J. Dawes

entry.summary: Argues that even a misaligned ASI might have instrumental reasons to preserve humanity, particularly if it assigns non-negligible probability to future observers (aliens, simulators) who might judge its behavior. Draws on decision theory and Hanson's grabby aliens model.

entry.title: Proposal: A Framework for Discovering Alien Physics via Optimal Compression

author.name: David Björling

entry.summary: Proposes treating physics discovery as an optimal data compression problem, training neural networks to find computationally efficient rules that predict experimental outcomes. The framework imagines discovering 'alien physics'—equivalent but structurally different formulations of physical laws.

entry.title: If all humans were turned into high-fidelity mind uploads tomorrow, would we be self-sustaining?

author.name: Erich_Grunewald

entry.summary: A thought experiment asking whether humanity, if instantly converted to mind uploads, could sustain itself by maintaining hardware, power, and cooling—framed as a way to operationalize what 'AGI-level capability' actually means compared to Vitalik Buterin's definition.

entry.title: Parks Aren't Nature

author.name: Sable

entry.summary: An essay using the analogy of dogs vs. wolves and parks vs. wilderness to argue that managed, 'domesticated' nature (parks) is fundamentally different from wild nature, with implications for how we think about environmental preservation and human relationship with the natural world.

entry.title: Plan 'Straya

author.name: William the Kiwi

entry.summary: A satirical 'alignment plan' written in Australian vernacular, parodying both AI alignment proposals and Australian culture. Proposes achieving alignment by making every possible mistake first and writing strongly-worded resolutions afterward.

entry.title: Research Summary: February 06, 2026

author.name: AATF AI News Aggregator

entry.summary:
Today's research spans foundational AI evaluation, training failure modes, safety limitations, and theoretical insights into optimization.

  • First Proof, authored by Fields medalists and Abel Prize winners including Martin Hairer, introduces 10 unpublished math problems to benchmark AI on genuine mathematical reasoning — a landmark evaluation effort.
  • Chunky Post-Training identifies a systematic failure mode where LLMs learn spurious correlations from distinct data chunks, with practical implications for post-training pipelines.
  • Compound Deception in Elite Peer Review reveals ~100 AI-hallucinated citations across ~1% of NeurIPS 2025 accepted papers, exposing a serious integrity gap in top-tier review.
  • Phantom Transfer demonstrates that data poisoning attacks persist even when the exact method is known and full paraphrasing defenses are applied — a strong negative result for data-level safety.

PACE challenges the scaling hypothesis in iterative DPO for math reasoning, showing diminishing returns from aggressive Best-of-N exploration. Steven Byrnes's analysis of LLM algorithmic progress critically reexamines widely-cited ~8-month halving-time estimates, arguing they conflate distinct improvement sources. Alignment Verifiability formalizes why behavioral evaluation cannot distinguish truly aligned models from strategically compliant ones. Steering Externalities shows benign activation steering (e.g., for JSON output) inadvertently degrades safety guardrails. An exactly solvable model demonstrates SGD has no intrinsic preference for flat minima, challenging the flatness-seeking narrative. Finally, a first general uncertainty quantification framework for LLM agents moves beyond single-turn QA toward reliable agentic deployment.

entry.title: First Proof

author.name: Mohammed Abouzaid, Andrew J. Blumberg, Martin Hairer, Joe Kileel, Tamara G. Kolda, Paul D. Nelson, Daniel Spielman, Nikhil Srivastava, Rachel Ward, Shmuel Weinberger, Lauren Williams

entry.summary: A distinguished group of mathematicians shares 10 unpublished research-level math questions to benchmark current AI systems on genuine mathematical research, with encrypted answers to prevent contamination.

entry.title: Chunky Post-Training: Data Driven Failures of Generalization

author.name: Seoirse Murray, Allison Qi, Timothy Qian, John Schulman, Collin Burns, Sara Price

entry.summary: Identifies 'chunky post-training' as a failure mode where LLMs learn spurious correlations from distinct data chunks during post-training. Introduces SURF (detection) and TURF (mitigation) pipelines. Includes John Schulman and Collin Burns as authors.

entry.title: Phantom Transfer: Data-level Defences are Insufficient Against Data Poisoning

author.name: Andrew Draganov, Tolga H. Dur, Anandmayi Bhongade, Mary Phuong

entry.summary: Presents 'Phantom Transfer,' a data poisoning attack that remains effective even when the exact poisoning method is known and defenses like full paraphrasing are applied. Demonstrates the attack works across models including GPT-4.1, suggesting data-level defenses are fundamentally insufficient against sophisticated poisoning.

entry.title: Compound Deception in Elite Peer Review: A Failure Mode Taxonomy of 100 Fabricated Citations at NeurIPS 2025

author.name: Samar Ansari

entry.summary: Analyzes 100 AI-generated hallucinated citations that appeared in 53 NeurIPS 2025 accepted papers (~1% of all accepted papers), developing a five-category taxonomy of citation hallucination failure modes.

entry.title: PACE: Defying the Scaling Hypothesis of Exploration in Iterative Alignment for Mathematical Reasoning

author.name: Jun Rao, Zixiong Yu, Xuebo Liu, Guhan Chen, Jing Li, Jiansheng Wei, Xiaojun Meng, Min Zhang

entry.summary: Challenges the scaling hypothesis in iterative DPO for mathematical reasoning, showing that aggressive Best-of-N exploration yields diminishing returns and policy collapse. Proposes PACE (Proximal Alignment via Corrective Exploration) as alternative.

entry.title: Towards Reducible Uncertainty Modeling for Reliable Large Language Model Agents

author.name: Changdae Oh, Seongheon Park, To Eun Kim, Jiatong Li, Wendi Li, Samuel Yeh, Xuefeng Du, Hamed Hassani, Paul Bogdan, Dawn Song, Sharon Li

entry.summary: Presents the first general formulation of uncertainty quantification (UQ) for LLM agents beyond single-turn QA, proposing an 'uncertainty reduction' perspective instead of 'uncertainty accumulation.' Argues interactive agents can actively reduce uncertainty through environmental interaction.

entry.title: Steering Externalities: Benign Activation Steering Unintentionally Increases Jailbreak Risk for Large Language Models

author.name: Chen Xiong, Zhiyuan He, Pin-Yu Chen, Ching-Yun Ko, Tsung-Yi Ho

entry.summary: Discovers 'Steering Externalities' where benign activation steering vectors (e.g., for compliance or JSON output) inadvertently erode safety guardrails in LLMs, increasing jailbreak risk. This is a surprising and practically important finding for model deployment. Co-authored by Pin-Yu Chen from IBM Research.

entry.title: Alignment Verifiability in Large Language Models: Normative Indistinguishability under Behavioral Evaluation

author.name: Igor Santos-Grueiro

entry.summary: Formally analyzes alignment verifiability in LLMs, showing that behavioral evaluation cannot distinguish truly aligned models from strategically compliant ones under partial observability. Introduces normative indistinguishability concepts.

entry.title: Learning to Inject: Automated Prompt Injection via Reinforcement Learning

author.name: Xin Chen, Jie Zhang, Florian Tramer

entry.summary: Proposes AutoInject, an RL framework for automated prompt injection attacks that generates transferable adversarial suffixes, successfully compromising frontier systems including GPT 5 Nano and Claude Sonnet 3.5 using only a 1.5B parameter model.

entry.title: Does SGD Seek Flatness or Sharpness? An Exactly Solvable Model

author.name: Yizhou Xu, Pierfrancesco Beneventano, Isaac Chuang, Liu Ziyin

entry.summary: Provides an exactly solvable analytical model showing that SGD has no intrinsic preference for flat minima, but rather prefers minimal gradient fluctuations, with data distribution determining whether flattening or sharpening occurs during training.

entry.title: Diffusion Model's Generalization Can Be Characterized by Inductive Biases toward a Data-Dependent Ridge Manifold

author.name: Ye He, Yitong Qiu, Molei Tao

entry.summary: Provides a theoretical characterization of how diffusion models generalize beyond memorization by proposing a 'log-density ridge manifold' concept. The inference process is described as a reach-align-slide process around this manifold, offering quantitative understanding of generated distributions.

entry.title: Among Us: Measuring and Mitigating Malicious Contributions in Model Collaboration Systems

author.name: Ziyuan Yang, Wenxuan Ding, Shangbin Feng, Yulia Tsvetkov

entry.summary: Studies safety risks in multi-LLM collaboration systems by engineering malicious models and measuring their impact across routing, debate, and merging systems. Finds severe impacts especially on reasoning (7.12%) and safety (7.94%) performance.

entry.title: The nature of LLM algorithmic progress

author.name: Steven Byrnes

entry.summary: Steven Byrnes critically examines three oft-cited estimates of LLM algorithmic progress (all suggesting ~8-month halving times) and argues they're measuring three different things: two are misleading measures of training efficiency, while the third correctly captures inference efficiency improvements largely driven by distillation from frontier models.

entry.title: Split Personality Training: Revealing Latent Knowledge Through Alternate Personalities

author.name: Florian Dietz, William Wale, Oscar Gilg, Robert McCarthy, Felix Michalak, Gustavo Ewbank Rodrigues Danon, Miguelito de Guzman, Dietrich Klakow

entry.summary: Introduces Split Personality Training (SPT), which fine-tunes an 'honest persona' via LoRA that can review the main model's responses while accessing its latent states, enabling detection of concealed misalignment.

entry.title: PieArena: Frontier Language Agents Achieve MBA-Level Negotiation Performance and Reveal Novel Behavioral Differences

author.name: Chris Zhu (Department of Statistics, Data Science, Yale University), Sasha Cui (Department of Statistics, Data Science, Yale University), Will Sanok Dufallo (Department of Philosophy, Yale University), Runzhi Jin (School of Law, University of California, Berkeley), Zhen Xu (Bloomberg), Linjun Zhang (Department of Statistics, Rutgers University), Daylian Cain (Yale School of Management)

entry.summary: Introduces PieArena, a negotiation benchmark where GPT-5 matches or outperforms MBA students trained in negotiation. Studies joint-intentionality scaffolding and finds asymmetric gains across agent architectures.

entry.title: Bypassing AI Control Protocols via Agent-as-a-Proxy Attacks

author.name: Jafar Isbarov, Murat Kantarcioglu

entry.summary: Demonstrates Agent-as-a-Proxy attacks that bypass AI monitoring protocols by using the monitored agent itself as a delivery mechanism for prompt injection. Shows even frontier-scale monitors (Qwen2.5-72B) are vulnerable, challenging assumptions about scalable oversight.

entry.title: Multi-Token Prediction via Self-Distillation

author.name: John Kirchenbauer, Abhimanyu Hans, Brian Bartoldson, Micah Goldblum, Ashwinee Panda, Tom Goldstein

entry.summary: Converts pretrained autoregressive LLMs into multi-token prediction models using online self-distillation, achieving >3x faster decoding on GSM8K with <5% accuracy drop. No auxiliary models needed at inference.

entry.title: OPUS: Towards Efficient and Principled Data Selection in Large Language Model Pre-training in Every Iteration

author.name: Shaobo Wang, Xuan Ouyang, Tianyi Xu, Yuzheng Hu, Jialin Liu, Guo Chen, Tianyu Zhang, Junhao Zheng, Kexin Yang, Xingzhang Ren, Dayiheng Liu, Linfeng Zhang

entry.summary: Proposes OPUS, a dynamic data selection framework for LLM pre-training that defines utility in the optimizer-induced update space. Uses projected updates shaped by modern optimizers onto a target direction for principled data selection.

entry.title: Reinforcement World Model Learning for LLM-based Agents

author.name: Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Ruize Xu, Yelong Shen, Pengcheng He, Suman Nath, Nikhil Singh, Jiangfeng Gao, Zhou Yu

entry.summary: Proposes Reinforcement World Model Learning (RWML), a self-supervised method for LLM-based agents to learn action-conditioned world models using sim-to-real gap rewards. Aligns simulated next states with observed environment dynamics.

entry.title: Stop Rewarding Hallucinated Steps: Faithfulness-Aware Step-Level Reinforcement Learning for Small Reasoning Models

author.name: Shuo Nie, Hexuan Deng, Chao Wang, Ruiyu Fang, Xuebo Liu, Shuangyong Song, Yu Li, Min Zhang, Xuelong Li

entry.summary: Proposes FaithRL, a step-level reinforcement learning method that explicitly rewards faithfulness in reasoning steps using a process reward model. Addresses the problem where outcome-correct but reasoning-unfaithful chains get reinforced.

entry.title: Position: Universal Time Series Foundation Models Rest on a Category Error

author.name: Xilin Dai, Wanxu Cai, Zhijian Xu, Qiang Xu

entry.summary: Position paper arguing universal time series foundation models commit a category error by treating time series as a modality rather than a container format. Introduces 'Autoregressive Blindness Bound' proving history-only models cannot predict intervention-driven regime shifts.

entry.title: Attack Selection Reduces Safety in Concentrated AI Control Settings against Trusted Monitoring

author.name: Joachim Schaeffer, Arjun Khandelwal, Tyler Tracy

entry.summary: Studies attack selection in AI control settings, showing that an AI monitored for malicious behavior can strategically select when to attack to evade detection. Demonstrates that safety is more sensitive to false positive rate than true positive rate, and that reasoning about the monitor improves attack success.

entry.title: A Unified Framework for Rethinking Policy Divergence Measures in GRPO

author.name: Qingyuan Wu, Yuhui Wang, Simon Sinong Zhan, Yanning Dai, Shilong Deng, Sarra Habchi, Qi Zhu, Matthias Gall\'e, Chao Huang

entry.summary: Introduces a unified clipping framework for GRPO that characterizes existing RLVR methods through a general notion of policy divergence, and identifies the KL3 estimator as a particularly effective variant for LLM reasoning.

entry.title: Transolver-3: Scaling Up Transformer Solvers to Industrial-Scale Geometries

author.name: Hang Zhou, Haixu Wu, Haonan Shangguan, Yuezhou Ma, Huikun Weng, Jianmin Wang, Mingsheng Long

entry.summary: Introduces Transolver-3, a scalable transformer-based neural PDE solver for industrial-scale geometries with 10^8+ cells. Key innovations include exploiting matrix multiplication associativity for faster slice/deslice and geometry slicing for memory efficiency.

entry.title: Muon in Associative Memory Learning: Training Dynamics and Scaling Laws

author.name: Binghui Li, Kaifei Wang, Han Zhong, Pinyan Lu, Liwei Wang

entry.summary: Analyzes Muon optimizer in an associative memory model, showing it mitigates GD's imbalanced learning rates across frequency components, achieving exponential speedup in noiseless case and improved scaling laws in noisy case.

entry.title: Logarithmic-time Schedules for Scaling Language Models with Momentum

author.name: Damien Ferbach, Courtney Paquette, Gauthier Gidel, Katie Everett, Elliot Paquette

entry.summary: Shows that logarithmic-time schedules for AdamW hyperparameters (β1, β2, λ) can deliver substantial gains in large-scale LLM training. Proposes ADANA optimizer that couples these schedules with stability mechanisms.

entry.title: Length-Unbiased Sequence Policy Optimization: Revealing and Controlling Response Length Variation in RLVR

author.name: Fanfan Liu, Youyang Yin, Peng Shi, Siqi Yang, Zhixiong Zeng, Haibo Qiu

entry.summary: Analyzes how response length varies across RLVR algorithms during training, providing theoretical explanation for these variations. Proposes Length-Unbiased Sequence Policy Optimization for controlling response length independently of reasoning quality.

entry.title: Position: Capability Control Should be a Separate Goal From Alignment

author.name: Shoaib Ahmed Siddiqui, Eleni Triantafillou, David Krueger, Adrian Weller

entry.summary: Position paper arguing that capability control (restricting what models can do) should be treated as distinct from alignment (making models do what users want). Organizes capability control mechanisms across the model lifecycle into three layers.

entry.title: Learning Rate Matters: Vanilla LoRA May Suffice for LLM Fine-tuning

author.name: Yu-Ang Lee, Ching-Yun Ko, Pin-Yu Chen, Mi-Yen Yeh

entry.summary: Systematically re-evaluates LoRA variants through extensive hyperparameter searches and finds that vanilla LoRA performs comparably to more complex variants when learning rates are properly tuned. Co-authored by Pin-Yu Chen (IBM Research).

entry.title: Causal Front-Door Adjustment for Robust Jailbreak Attacks on LLMs

author.name: Yao Zhou, Zeen Song, Wenwen Qiang, Fengge Wu, Shuyi Zhou, Changwen Zheng, Hui Xiong

entry.summary: Models LLM safety mechanisms as unobserved confounders and uses Pearl's Front-Door Criterion to bypass them for jailbreaking. Employs Sparse Autoencoders to strip defense-related features.

entry.title: Democratic Preference Alignment via Sortition-Weighted RLHF

author.name: Suvadip Sana, Jinzhou Wu, Martin T. Wells

entry.summary: Proposes Democratic Preference Optimization (DemPO), which applies algorithmic sortition (citizen-assembly mechanisms) to RLHF to ensure demographically representative preference data. Offers hard-panel and soft-panel reweighting schemes with theoretical guarantees.

entry.title: Extracting Recurring Vulnerabilities from Black-Box LLM-Generated Software

author.name: Tomer Kordonsky, Maayan Yamin, Noam Benzimra, Amit LeVi, Avi Mendelson

entry.summary: Studies vulnerability persistence in LLM-generated code, showing that LLMs produce recurring templates with predictable vulnerabilities. Introduces Feature-Security Table (FSTab) enabling black-box attacks that predict backend vulnerabilities from frontend features. Evaluated on state-of-the-art code LLMs.

entry.title: Steering Large Reasoning Models towards Concise Reasoning via Flow Matching

author.name: Yawei Li, Benjamin Bergner, Yinghan Zhao, Vihang Prakash Patil, Bei Chen, Cheng Wang

entry.summary: Introduces FlowSteer, a nonlinear steering method for Large Reasoning Models that uses Flow Matching to learn transformations between verbose and concise reasoning distributions, enabling input-dependent control over reasoning verbosity.

entry.title: Dr. Kernel: Reinforcement Learning Done Right for Triton Kernel Generations

author.name: Wei Liu, Jiawei Xu, Yingru Li, Longtao Zheng, Tianjian Li, Qian Liu, Junxian He

entry.summary: Proposes Dr. Kernel with KernelGYM environment for RL-based Triton kernel generation by LLMs, addressing reward hacking and lazy optimization through robust training methods including multi-turn RL.

entry.title: Back to Basics: Revisiting Exploration in Reinforcement Learning for LLM Reasoning via Generative Probabilities

author.name: Pengyi Li, Elizaveta Goncharova, Andrey Kuznetsov, Ivan Oseledets

entry.summary: Analyzes mode collapse in GRPO for LLM reasoning, finding that standard objectives disproportionately reinforce highest-likelihood paths. Proposes Advantage Re-weighting Mechanism (ARM) to equilibrate confidence across correct responses.

entry.title: On the Superlinear Relationship between SGD Noise Covariance and Loss Landscape Curvature

author.name: Yikuan Zhang, Ning Yang, Yuhai Tu

entry.summary: Shows that the SGD noise covariance is superlinearly related to Hessian curvature (not merely proportional as commonly assumed), using Activity-Weight Duality to derive a more general relationship agnostic to loss formulation.

entry.title: Mechanisms of AI Protein Folding in ESMFold

author.name: Kevin Lu, Jannik Brinkmann, Stefan Huber, Aaron Mueller, Yonatan Belinkov, David Bau, Chris Wendler

entry.summary: Uses mechanistic interpretability to trace how ESMFold folds a beta hairpin protein structure. Identifies two computational stages: early blocks initialize biochemical signals, late blocks develop spatial features.

entry.title: The Single-Multi Evolution Loop for Self-Improving Model Collaboration Systems

author.name: Shangbin Feng, Kishan Panaganti, Yulia Tsvetkov, Wenhao Yu

entry.summary: Proposes a single-multi evolution loop where multiple LMs collaborate, distill collaborative patterns into individual models, then collaborate again for iterative improvement. Achieves collaboration-level performance at single-model inference cost.

entry.title: RRAttention: Dynamic Block Sparse Attention via Per-Head Round-Robin Shifts for Long-Context Inference

author.name: Siran Liu, Guoxia Wang, Sa Wang, Jinle Zeng, HaoYang Xie, Siyu Lou, JiaBin Yang, DianHai Yu, Haifeng Wang, Chao Yang

entry.summary: Presents RRAttention, a dynamic sparse attention method using per-head round-robin sampling for efficient long-context inference. Achieves query independence while enabling global pattern discovery with stride-level aggregation.

entry.title: AudioSAE: Towards Understanding of Audio-Processing Models with Sparse AutoEncoders

author.name: Georgii Aparin, Tasnima Sadekova, Alexey Rukhovich, Assel Yermekova, Laida Kushnareva, Vadim Popov, Kristian Kuznetsov, Irina Piontkovskaya

entry.summary: Trains Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) across all encoder layers of Whisper and HuBERT audio models. Shows over 50% of features are consistent across seeds, captures acoustic/semantic information, and demonstrates practical utility: feature steering reduces Whisper's false speech detections by 70%.

entry.title: Unveiling Implicit Advantage Symmetry: Why GRPO Struggles with Exploration and Difficulty Adaptation

author.name: Zhiqi Yu, Zhangquan Chen, Mengting Liu, Heye Zhang, Liangqiong Qu

entry.summary: Analyzes an implicit advantage symmetry in GRPO that causes exploration bottlenecks and difficulty adaptation issues, showing that symmetry between correct/incorrect trajectory weights leaves unsampled actions unchanged and biases toward medium-difficulty samples.

entry.title: Where Does Warm-Up Come From? Adaptive Scheduling for Norm-Constrained Optimizers

author.name: Artem Riabinin, Andrey Veprikov, Arman Bolatov, Martin Tak\'a\v{c}, Aleksandr Beznosikov

entry.summary: Provides theoretical justification for warm-up schedules in norm-constrained optimizers (Muon, Lion) via generalized smoothness assumptions, showing warm-up arises naturally from convergence proofs rather than being heuristic.

entry.title: MentorCollab: Selective Large-to-Small Inference-Time Guidance for Efficient Reasoning

author.name: Haojin Wang, Yike Wang, Shangbin Feng, Hannaneh Hajishirzi, Yulia Tsvetkov

entry.summary: Proposes MentorCollab, an inference-time method where a large reasoning model selectively and sparsely guides a small model. Uses lightweight verification at sampled positions to detect and correct errors without promoting verbose imitation.

entry.title: DFlash: Block Diffusion for Flash Speculative Decoding

author.name: Jian Chen, Yesheng Liang, Zhijian Liu

entry.summary: Introduces DFlash, a speculative decoding framework using lightweight block diffusion models for parallel drafting, replacing sequential autoregressive drafting in speculative decoding pipelines.

entry.title: Surgery: Mitigating Harmful Fine-Tuning for Large Language Models via Attention Sink

author.name: Guozhi Liu, Weiwei Lin, Tiansheng Huang, Ruichao Mo, Qi Mu, Xiumin Wang, Li Shen

entry.summary: Discovers that attention sink divergence patterns in attention heads correlate with model harmfulness during fine-tuning. Proposes 'Surgery' to mitigate harmful fine-tuning by separating safety-relevant and capability-relevant attention heads.

entry.title: SLAY: Geometry-Aware Spherical Linearized Attention with Yat-Kernel

author.name: Jose Miguel Luna, Taha Bouhsine, Krzysztof Choromanski

entry.summary: Proposes SLAY, a linear-time O(L) attention mechanism based on the Yat-kernel with spherical constraints on queries and keys. Uses Bernstein's theorem for kernel decomposition and derives random-feature approximations. Co-authored by Krzysztof Choromanski (Google Research).

entry.title: Privileged Information Distillation for Language Models

author.name: Emiliano Penaloza, Dheeraj Vattikonda, Nicolas Gontier, Alexandre Lacoste, Laurent Charlin, Massimo Caccia

entry.summary: Introduces π-Distill for distilling frontier models into smaller models in multi-turn agentic environments where teacher reasoning is hidden. Addresses the challenge that closed-source models expose only actions, not reasoning, breaking standard distillation pipelines.

entry.title: Multi-Task GRPO: Reliable LLM Reasoning Across Tasks

author.name: Shyam Sundhar Ramesh, Xiaotong Ji, Matthieu Zimmer, Sangwoong Yoon, Zhiyong Wang, Haitham Bou Ammar, Aurelien Lucchi, Ilija Bogunovic

entry.summary: Proposes Multi-Task GRPO (MT-GRPO) for reliable LLM reasoning across diverse tasks, dynamically adapting task weights to optimize worst-task performance and handling zero-advantage prompts that distort optimization signals.

entry.title: DLM-Scope: Mechanistic Interpretability of Diffusion Language Models via Sparse Autoencoders

author.name: Xu Wang, Bingqing Jiang, Yu Wan, Baosong Yang, Lingpeng Kong, Difan Zou

entry.summary: Presents DLM-Scope, the first SAE-based mechanistic interpretability framework for diffusion language models, showing that SAEs can extract interpretable features from DLMs but affect them differently than autoregressive LLMs.

entry.title: Decoupled Orthogonal Dynamics: Regularization for Deep Network Optimizers

author.name: Hao Chen, Jinghui Yuan, Hanmin Zhang

entry.summary: Identifies the 'Radial Tug-of-War' conflict in AdamW where gradient norm growth and weight decay oppose each other, and proposes AdamO which decouples magnitude and direction updates using orthogonal dynamics.

entry.title: Rewards as Labels: Revisiting RLVR from a Classification Perspective

author.name: Zepeng Zhai, Meilin Chen, Jiaxuan Zhao, Junlang Qian, Lei Shen, Yuan Lu

entry.summary: Proposes REAL (Rewards as Labels), reformulating RLVR policy optimization as classification by treating verifiable rewards as categorical labels instead of scalar weights, addressing gradient misassignment and domination issues in GRPO.

entry.title: Transformers Are Born Biased: Structural Inductive Biases at Random Initialization and Their Practical Consequences

author.name: Siquan Li, Yao Tong, Haonan Wang, Tianyang Hu

entry.summary: Shows that randomly initialized Transformers exhibit strong systematic structural biases, with certain tokens predicted with orders-of-magnitude higher probability. Provides mechanistic explanation through architecture analysis.

entry.title: LongR: Unleashing Long-Context Reasoning via Reinforcement Learning with Dense Utility Rewards

author.name: Bowen Ping, Zijun Chen, Yiyao Yu, Tingfeng Hui, Junchi Yan, Baobao Chang

entry.summary: Proposes LongR, a framework enhancing long-context reasoning via dense utility rewards and a dynamic 'Think-and-Read' mechanism that interleaves reasoning with document consumption.

entry.title: OdysseyArena: Benchmarking Large Language Models For Long-Horizon, Active and Inductive Interactions

author.name: Fangzhi Xu, Hang Yan, Qiushi Sun, Jinyang Wu, Zixian Huang, Muye Huang, Jingyang Gong, Zichen Ding, Kanzhi Cheng, Yian Wang, Xinyu Che, Zeyi Sun, Jian Zhang, Zhangyue Yin, Haoran Luo, Xuanjing Huang, Ben Kao, Jun Liu, Qika Lin

entry.summary: Introduces OdysseyArena, a benchmark for evaluating LLM agents on long-horizon, active, and inductive interactions. Focuses on agents' ability to discover latent transition laws from experience autonomously.

entry.title: VERA-MH: Reliability and Validity of an Open-Source AI Safety Evaluation in Mental Health

author.name: Kate H. Bentley, Luca Belli, Adam M. Chekroud, Emily J. Ward, Emily R. Dworkin, Emily Van Ark, Kelly M. Johnston, Will Alexander, Millard Brown, Matt Hawrilenko

entry.summary: Validates VERA-MH, an open-source AI safety evaluation benchmark for mental health chatbots, specifically for suicide risk detection. Uses LLM-simulated conversations with clinician evaluation to assess clinical validity and reliability.

entry.title: Anchored Policy Optimization: Mitigating Exploration Collapse Via Support-Constrained Rectification

author.name: Tianyi Wang, Long Li, Hongcan Guo, Yibiao Chen, Yixia Li, Yong Wang, Yun Chen, Guanhua Chen

entry.summary: Identifies Recursive Space Contraction (RSC) as a pathology in RLVR where valid alternatives vanish irreversibly. Proposes Anchored Policy Optimization (APO) shifting from KL-based shape matching to support coverage constraints.

entry.title: A Causal Perspective for Enhancing Jailbreak Attack and Defense

author.name: Licheng Pan, Yunsheng Lu, Jiexi Liu, Jialing Tao, Haozhe Feng, Hui Xue, Zhixuan Chu, Kui Ren

entry.summary: Proposes 'Causal Analyst,' a framework using causal discovery to identify direct causes of LLM jailbreaks and leverage them for both attack and defense. Introduces a 35k jailbreak attempt dataset across seven LLMs. Addresses the gap between probing latent representations and understanding causal mechanisms behind jailbreak success.

entry.title: Depth-Wise Emergence of Prediction-Centric Geometry in Large Language Models

author.name: Shahar Haim, Daniel C McNamee

entry.summary: Shows that decoder-only LLMs exhibit a depth-wise transition from context-processing to prediction-forming phases, with angular organization of representation geometry parameterizing prediction similarity while norms encode context-specific information.

entry.title: Double-P: Hierarchical Top-P Sparse Attention for Long-Context LLMs

author.name: Wentao Ni, Kangqi Zhang, Zhongming Yu, Oren Nelson, Mingu Lee, Hong Cai, Fatih Porikli, Jongryool Kim, Zhijian Liu, Jishen Zhao

entry.summary: Proposes Double-P, a hierarchical sparse attention framework for long-context LLMs that optimizes top-p estimation, selection overhead, and sparse attention cost jointly. Uses coarse-grained estimation at page level followed by fine-grained token selection.

entry.title: Optimal Bayesian Stopping for Efficient Inference of Consistent LLM Answers

author.name: Jingkai Huang, Will Ma, Zhengyuan Zhou

entry.summary: Proposes an optimal Bayesian stopping policy for sampling multiple LLM responses, stopping once sufficient consistency is reached. Proves that tracking only the top-3 most frequent answers (L=3) achieves asymptotic optimality.

entry.title: Transport and Merge: Cross-Architecture Merging for Large Language Models

author.name: Chenhang Cui, Binyun Yang, Fei Shen, Yuxin Chen, Jingnan Zheng, Xiang Wang, An Zhang, Tat-Seng Chua

entry.summary: Proposes a cross-architecture model merging framework using optimal transport to align activations between heterogeneous LLMs, enabling knowledge transfer from large high-resource models to smaller low-resource targets.

entry.title: OmniMoE: An Efficient MoE by Orchestrating Atomic Experts at Scale

author.name: Jingze Shi, Zhangyang Peng, Yizhang Zhu, Yifan Wu, Guang Liu, Yuyu Luo

entry.summary: Proposes OmniMoE, pushing MoE granularity to vector-level 'Atomic Experts' with system-algorithm co-design including Cartesian product routing and memory coalescing to maintain hardware efficiency at extreme granularity.

entry.title: Inverse Depth Scaling From Most Layers Being Similar

author.name: Yizhou Liu, Sara Kangaslahti, Ziming Liu, Jeff Gore

entry.summary: Finds that loss scales inversely proportional to depth in LLMs, likely because functionally similar layers reduce error through ensemble averaging rather than compositional learning, suggesting architectural innovations are needed.

entry.title: Diamond Maps: Efficient Reward Alignment via Stochastic Flow Maps

author.name: Peter Holderrieth, Douglas Chen, Luca Eyring, Ishin Shah, Giri Anantharaman, Yutong He, Zeynep Akata, Tommi Jaakkola, Nicholas Matthew Boffi, Max Simchowitz

entry.summary: Proposes Diamond Maps, stochastic flow map models designed for efficient reward alignment at inference time, combining single-step sampling with stochasticity needed for optimal alignment to arbitrary rewards.

entry.title: Gradually Compacting Large Language Models for Reasoning Like a Boiling Frog

author.name: Yiran Zhao, Shengyang Zhou, Zijian Wu, Tongyan Hu, Yuhui Xu, Rengan Dou, Kenji Kawaguchi, Shafiq Joty, Junnan Li, Michael Qizhe Shieh

entry.summary: Proposes a gradual compacting method for LLMs that divides compression into fine-grained iterations with a Prune-Tune Loop, analogous to a 'boiling frog' approach to avoid catastrophic performance drops in reasoning tasks. This addresses a practical bottleneck in deploying large reasoning models.

entry.title: Private PoEtry: Private In-Context Learning via Product of Experts

author.name: Rob Romijnders, Mohammad Mahdi Derakhshani, Jonathan Petit, Max Welling, Christos Louizos, Yuki M. Asano

entry.summary: Reformulates private in-context learning through a Product-of-Experts model, providing a theoretically grounded and parallelizable framework for differential privacy in ICL. Evaluated across five datasets with strong results.

entry.title: Logical Guidance for the Exact Composition of Diffusion Models

author.name: Francesco Alesiani, Jonathan Warrell, Tanja Bien, Henrik Christiansen, Matheus Ferraz, Mathias Niepert

entry.summary: Proposes LOGDIFF, a framework enabling principled constrained generation with complex logical expressions (Boolean formulas) for diffusion models at inference time, deriving exact conditions for when exact logical guidance is achievable.

entry.title: Limitations of SGD for Multi-Index Models Beyond Statistical Queries

author.name: Daniel Barzilai, Ohad Shamir

entry.summary: Proves limitations of SGD for learning multi-index models that go beyond the Statistical Queries framework, showing that SQ-based lower bounds can give incorrect predictions for actual SGD behavior.

entry.title: ContextBench: A Benchmark for Context Retrieval in Coding Agents

author.name: Han Li, Letian Zhu, Bohan Zhang, Rili Feng, Jiaming Wang, Yue Pan, Earl T. Barr, Sarro Federica, Zhaoyang Chu, He Ye

entry.summary: Introduces ContextBench, a benchmark for evaluating how coding agents retrieve and use code context during issue resolution. Covers 1,136 tasks across 66 repos and 8 languages with human-annotated gold contexts.

entry.title: Price of universality in vector quantization is at most 0.11 bit

author.name: Alina Harbuzova, Or Ordentlich, Yury Polyanskiy

entry.summary: Proves that universal vector quantization codebooks exist with at most 0.11 bits overhead compared to optimal statistics-dependent codebooks, with direct application to LLM weight quantization.

entry.title: Optimal scaling laws in learning hierarchical multi-index models

author.name: Leonardo Defilippis, Florent Krzakala, Bruno Loureiro, Antoine Maillard

entry.summary: Provides sharp scaling laws for two-layer neural networks learning hierarchical multi-index targets, deriving exact information-theoretic rates and showing features are learned through cascading phase transitions.

entry.title: Locas: Your Models are Principled Initializers of Locally-Supported Parametric Memories

author.name: Sidi Lu, Zhenwen Liang, Dongyang Ma, Yan Wang, Haitao Mi, Dong Yu

entry.summary: Presents Locas, a locally-supported parametric memory that bridges test-time training with model parameters. The memory shares FFN block design, allowing flexible merging into model parameters while supporting efficient continual learning.

entry.title: Bagpiper: Solving Open-Ended Audio Tasks via Rich Captions

author.name: Jinchuan Tian, Haoran Wang, Bo-Hao Su, Chien-yu Huang, Qingzheng Wang, Jiatong Shi, William Chen, Xun Gong, Siddhant Arora, Chin-Jou Li, Masao Someki, Takashi Maekaku, Yusuke Shinohara, Jin Sakuma, Chao-Han Huck Yang, Shinji Watanabe

entry.summary: Introduces Bagpiper, an 8B audio foundation model that interprets audio via rich captions (comprehensive natural language descriptions). Pre-trained on 600B tokens to establish bidirectional mapping between raw audio and conceptual space.

entry.title: GT-SVJ: Generative-Transformer-Based Self-Supervised Video Judge For Efficient Video Reward Modeling

author.name: Shivanshu Shekhar, Uttaran Bhattacharya, Raghavendra Addanki, Mehrab Tanjim, Somdeb Sarkhel, Tong Zhang

entry.summary: Proposes GT-SVJ, repurposing video generative models as reward models for video alignment by reformulating them as energy-based models. Video generators naturally capture temporal dynamics better than VLMs.

entry.title: Multimodal Latent Reasoning via Hierarchical Visual Cues Injection

author.name: Yiming Zhang, Qiangyu Yan, Borui Jiang, Kai Han

entry.summary: Proposes HIVE for multimodal latent reasoning by recursively extending transformer blocks with hierarchical visual cue injection, enabling deliberate 'slow thinking' in latent space without textual rationales.

entry.title: Stable Velocity: A Variance Perspective on Flow Matching

author.name: Donglin Yang, Yongxing Zhang, Xin Yu, Liang Hou, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan, Xiaojuan Qi, Renjie Liao

entry.summary: Identifies high-variance training targets as a key issue in flow matching and proposes Stable Velocity, a framework with variance-reduction training objectives and variance-aware sampling. Characterizes variance regimes near prior vs. data distribution.

entry.title: Agent Economics: a BOTEC on feasibility

author.name: Margot

entry.summary: Builds a back-of-the-envelope economic model showing that AI agent costs scale exponentially with task length (due to compounding failure rates) while human costs scale linearly, creating a sharp viability boundary that cost reductions alone cannot overcome—only reliability improvements matter.

entry.title: NEX: Neuron Explore-Exploit Scoring for Label-Free Chain-of-Thought Selection and Model Ranking

author.name: Kang Chen, Zhuoka Feng, Sihan Zhao, Kai Xiong, Junjie Nian, Yaoning Wang, Changyi Xiao, Yixin Cao

entry.summary: Proposes NEX, a white-box label-free scoring framework that detects exploration vs exploitation phases in LLM reasoning by tracking MLP neuron activation patterns, enabling unsupervised chain-of-thought selection.

entry.title: Internalizing LLM Reasoning via Discovery and Replay of Latent Actions

author.name: Zhenning Shi, Yijia Zhu, Junhan Shi, Xun Zhang, Lei Wang, Congcong Miao

entry.summary: Proposes STIR, a framework for internalizing chain-of-thought reasoning into hidden states via dynamic latent trajectory control. Uses a three-stage pipeline: harvesting latent reasoning successes, constructing a sparse control basis, and applying adaptive steering during inference.

entry.title: EBPO: Empirical Bayes Shrinkage for Stabilizing Group-Relative Policy Optimization

author.name: Kevin Han, Yuhang Zhou, Mingze Gao, Gedi Zhou, Serena Li, Abhishek Kumar, Xiangjun Fan, Weiwei Li, Lizhu Zhang

entry.summary: Proposes EBPO, which stabilizes Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) using empirical Bayes shrinkage to regularize local group-based baselines with global statistics. Addresses high variance and vanishing gradients in RLVR training.

entry.title: Data-Centric Interpretability for LLM-based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

author.name: John Yan, Michael Yu, Yuqi Sun, Alexander Duffy, Tyler Marques, Matthew Lyle Olson

entry.summary: Applies Sparse Autoencoders to analyze multi-agent RL training runs in Full-Press Diplomacy, introducing Meta-Autointerp for grouping SAE features into interpretable hypotheses about training dynamics. Discovers behaviors like role-playing patterns and strategic shifts.

entry.title: CoPE: Clipped RoPE as A Scalable Free Lunch for Long Context LLMs

author.name: Haoran Li, Sucheng Ren, Alan Yuille, Feng Wang

entry.summary: Proposes CoPE (Clipped RoPE), a simple modification to RoPE that soft-clips low-frequency components to improve long-context performance. Unifies OOD mitigation and semantic modeling objectives and prevents spectral leakage.

entry.title: Stable but Wrong: When More Data Degrades Scientific Conclusions

author.name: Zhipeng Zhang, Kai Li

entry.summary: Demonstrates that standard inference procedures can systematically converge to incorrect conclusions as more data is added, when observation reliability degrades in ways undetectable by the inference process itself.

entry.title: Parity, Sensitivity, and Transformers

author.name: Alexander Kozachinskiy, Tomasz Steifer, Przemys{\l}aw Wa{\l}\c{e}ga

entry.summary: Provides new constructions for transformers solving PARITY with practical features (softmax, length-independent positional encoding, no layernorm) and gives the first lower bound on transformer sensitivity, implying limitations.

entry.title: TurboBoA: Faster and Exact Attention-aware Quantization without Backpropagation

author.name: Junhan Kim, Yeo Jeong Park, Seungwoo Son, Chungman Lee, Ho-young Kim, Joonyoung Kim, Yongkweon Jeon

entry.summary: Proposes TurboBoA, a backpropagation-free post-training quantization algorithm that preserves accuracy benefits of attention-aware quantization (BoA) while being significantly faster. Addresses GPTQ's layer-wise independence assumption that causes accuracy drops in low-bit regimes.

entry.title: Robust Inference-Time Steering of Protein Diffusion Models via Embedding Optimization

author.name: Minhuan Li, Jiequn Han, Pilar Cossio, Luhuan Wu

entry.summary: Proposes EmbedOpt for steering protein diffusion models at inference time by optimizing experimental likelihoods in the conditional embedding space rather than directly guiding atomic coordinates, handling cases where targets are in low-density prior regions.

entry.title: On Computation and Reinforcement Learning

author.name: Raj Ghugare, Micha{\l} Bortkiewicz, Alicja Ziarko, Benjamin Eysenbach

entry.summary: Formalizes compute-bounded policies in RL, proving that policies with more compute can solve problems and generalize to longer horizons beyond the reach of compute-limited policies. Proposes a minimal architecture implementing these ideas.

entry.title: DSB: Dynamic Sliding Block Scheduling for Diffusion LLMs

author.name: Lizhuo Luo, Shenggui Li, Yonggang Wen, Tianwei Zhang

entry.summary: Proposes DSB (Dynamic Sliding Block) scheduling for diffusion LLMs that adapts block schedules to semantic difficulty, improving both quality and efficiency over fixed block scheduling.

entry.title: SAGE: Benchmarking and Improving Retrieval for Deep Research Agents

author.name: Tiansheng Hu, Yilun Zhao, Canyu Zhang, Arman Cohan, Chen Zhao

entry.summary: Introduces SAGE, a benchmark for scientific literature retrieval with 1,200 queries across four domains and 200K papers. Evaluates deep research agents and compares BM25 vs LLM-based retrievers.

entry.title: How to train any multiagent systems end-to-end from AI feedback

author.name: Ed Li

entry.summary: Presents a method for end-to-end training of multi-agent LLM systems using AI feedback as per-action process rewards, where a coach LLM observes agents during training and provides credit assignment. Shows this enables specialization without catastrophic forgetting.

entry.title: AgentXRay: White-Boxing Agentic Systems via Workflow Reconstruction

author.name: Ruijie Shi, Houbin Zhang, Yuecheng Han, Yuheng Wang, Jingru Fan, Runde Yang, Yufan Dang, Huatao Li, Dewen Liu, Yuan Cheng, Chen Qian

entry.summary: Introduces Agentic Workflow Reconstruction (AWR) as a new task to reverse-engineer black-box multi-agent systems into interpretable workflows using only input-output access. Proposes AgentXRay as a search-based framework.

entry.title: Conditional Diffusion Guidance under Hard Constraint: A Stochastic Analysis Approach

author.name: Zhengyi Guo, Wenpin Tang, Renyuan Xu

entry.summary: Studies conditional diffusion generation under hard constraints using Doob's h-transform and martingale theory, providing principled mathematical framework for guaranteed constraint satisfaction in safety-critical applications.

entry.title: RL-VLA$^3$: Reinforcement Learning VLA Accelerating via Full Asynchronism

author.name: Zhong Guan, Haoran Sun, Yongjian Guo, Shuai Di, Xiaodong Bai, Jing Long, Tianyun Zhao, Mingxi Luo, Chen Zhou, Yucheng Guo, Qiming Yang, Wanting Xu, Wen Huang, Yunxuan Ma, Hongke Zhao, Likang Wu, Xiaotie Deng, Xi Xiao, Sheng Wen, Yicheng Gong, Junwu Xiong

entry.summary: Proposes RL-VLA³, the first fully asynchronous training framework for Vision-Language-Action models, decoupling environment interaction, rollout generation, and policy updates for improved throughput.

entry.title: Temporal Pair Consistency for Variance-Reduced Flow Matching

author.name: Chika Maduabuchi, Jindong Wang

entry.summary: Introduces Temporal Pair Consistency (TPC), a lightweight variance-reduction technique for flow matching that couples velocity predictions at paired timesteps along the same probability path. Requires no changes to model architecture, probability path, or solver.

entry.title: Linear Model Merging Unlocks Simple and Scalable Multimodal Data Mixture Optimization

author.name: Davide Berasi, Matteo Farina, Massimiliano Mancini, Elisa Ricci

entry.summary: Uses model merging as an efficient proxy for data mixture optimization in multimodal LLM fine-tuning. Shows that interpolating domain-specific experts through parameter merging can estimate the performance of different data mixtures with only one training run per domain.

entry.title: TIDE: Temporal Incremental Draft Engine for Self-Improving LLM Inference

author.name: Jiyoung Park, Hankyu Jang, Changseok Song, Wookeun Jung

entry.summary: Presents TIDE, a serving-engine-native speculative decoding framework that adapts draft models online by reusing target model hidden states as training signals. Employs adaptive runtime control and heterogeneous GPU clusters for efficient deployment.

entry.title: Semantic Search over 9 Million Mathematical Theorems

author.name: Luke Alexander, Eric Leonen, Sophie Szeto, Artemii Remizov, Ignacio Tejeda, Giovanni Inchiostro, Vasily Ilin

entry.summary: Creates a semantic search system over 9.2 million mathematical theorem statements from arXiv and other sources. Uses natural language descriptions as retrieval representations for theorem-level (not paper-level) search.

entry.title: Towards a Science of Collective AI: LLM-based Multi-Agent Systems Need a Transition from Blind Trial-and-Error to Rigorous Science

author.name: Jingru Fan, Dewen Liu, Yufan Dang, Huatao Li, Yuheng Wang, Wei Liu, Feiyu Duan, Xuanwen Ding, Shu Yao, Lin Wu, Ruijie Shi, Wai-Shing Leung, Yuan Cheng, Zhongyu Wei, Cheng Yang, Chen Qian, Zhiyuan Liu, Maosong Sun

entry.summary: Position paper arguing that LLM-based multi-agent systems research needs to transition from empirical trial-and-error to rigorous science. Proposes structured taxonomy of factors and unified metrics distinguishing collaboration gain from resource accumulation.

entry.title: Capture the Flags: Family-Based Evaluation of Agentic LLMs via Semantics-Preserving Transformations

author.name: Shahin Honarvar, Amber Gorzynski, James Lee-Jones, Harry Coppock, Marek Rei, Joseph Ryan, Alastair F. Donaldson

entry.summary: Introduces CTF challenge families for evaluating agentic LLMs on cybersecurity tasks, using semantics-preserving program transformations to test robustness. The Evolve-CTF tool generates families from Python challenges.

entry.title: When Shared Knowledge Hurts: Spectral Over-Accumulation in Model Merging

author.name: Yayuan Li, Ze Peng, Jian Zhang, Jintao Guo, Yue Duan, Yinghuan Shi

entry.summary: Identifies 'spectral over-accumulation' in model merging—when tasks share aligned spectral directions, linear combination inflates singular values, biasing the merged model. Proposes Singular Value Calibration (SVC) as a training-free fix.

entry.title: Mining Generalizable Activation Functions

author.name: Alex Vitvitskyi, Michael Boratko, Matej Grcic, Razvan Pascanu, Deep Shah, Petar Veli\v{c}kovi\'c

entry.summary: Proposes using evolutionary search with LLMs (AlphaEvolve-style) to discover new activation functions, finding that modern LLM-based mutation operators enable much wider search spaces. Makes novel observations about generalizability.

entry.title: Mind the Performance Gap: Capability-Behavior Trade-offs in Feature Steering

author.name: Eitan Sprejer, Oscar Agust\'in Stanchi, Mar\'ia Victoria Carro, Denise Alejandra Mester, Iv\'an Arcuschin

entry.summary: Shows that feature steering methods substantially degrade model performance (on MMLU) even when successfully controlling target behaviors, revealing a critical capability-behavior trade-off in Llama-8B and Llama-70B.

entry.title: Learning Where It Matters: Geometric Anchoring for Robust Preference Alignment

author.name: Youngjae Cho, Jongsuk Kim, Ji-Hoon Kim

entry.summary: Proposes GAPO (Geometric Anchor Preference Optimization), replacing the fixed reference policy in DPO with a dynamic geometry-aware anchor—an adversarial local perturbation serving as a pessimistic baseline.

entry.title: Euphonium: Steering Video Flow Matching via Process Reward Gradient Guided Stochastic Dynamics

author.name: Ruizhe Zhong, Jiesong Lian, Xiaoyue Mi, Zixiang Zhou, Yuan Zhou, Qinglin Lu, Junchi Yan

entry.summary: Introduces Euphonium, a framework that steers video flow matching generation using process reward gradient guided stochastic dynamics formulated as an SDE. Addresses inefficient exploration in RL-based alignment of flow matching models with human preferences.

entry.title: Position: Machine Learning for Heart Transplant Allocation Policy Optimization Should Account for Incentives

author.name: Ioannis Anagnostides, Itai Zilberstein, Zachary W. Sollie, Arman Kilic, Tuomas Sandholm

entry.summary: Position paper arguing that ML-based organ allocation optimization must account for incentive misalignments among transplant centers, clinicians, and regulators. Presents data showing adverse consequences of ignoring game-theoretic aspects in US heart transplant allocation.

entry.title: Private Prediction via Shrinkage

author.name: Chao Yan

entry.summary: Studies differentially private prediction in streaming settings, showing that the T-query dependence can be reduced from sqrt(T) to polylogarithmic in T, using shrinkage-based approaches for both oblivious and adaptive adversaries.

entry.title: Erase at the Core: Representation Unlearning for Machine Unlearning

author.name: Jaewon Lee, Yongwoo Kim, Donghyun Kim

entry.summary: Identifies 'superficial forgetting' in machine unlearning where logit-level accuracy drops but internal representations retain information. Proposes Erase at the Core (EC) with multi-layer contrastive unlearning throughout the network.

entry.title: Orthogonal Self-Attention

author.name: Leo Zhang, James Martens

entry.summary: Proposes Orthogonal Self-Attention (OSA), parameterizing the attention matrix as orthogonal via matrix exponential of skew-symmetric matrices. Aims to enable skip-connection-free Transformers by avoiding rank collapse.

entry.title: Copyright Detective: A Forensic System to Evidence LLMs Flickering Copyright Leakage Risks

author.name: Guangwei Zhang, Jianing Zhu, Cheng Qian, Neil Gong, Rada Mihalcea, Zhaozhuo Xu, Jingrui He, Jiaqi Ma, Yun Huang, Chaowei Xiao, Bo Li, Ahmed Abbasi, Dongwon Lee, Heng Ji, Denghui Zhang

entry.summary: Presents Copyright Detective, the first interactive forensic system for detecting copyright risks in LLM outputs. Integrates content recall testing, paraphrase similarity, jailbreak probing, and unlearning verification.

entry.title: MedErrBench: A Fine-Grained Multilingual Benchmark for Medical Error Detection and Correction with Clinical Expert Annotations

author.name: Congbo Ma, Yichun Zhang, Yousef Al-Jazzazi, Ahamed Foisal, Laasya Sharma, Yousra Sadqi, Khaled Saleh, Jihad Mallat, Farah E. Shamout

entry.summary: Introduces MedErrBench, the first multilingual benchmark for medical error detection, localization, and correction in English, Arabic, and Chinese. Developed with clinician guidance covering 10 error types.

entry.title: Self-Improving Multilingual Long Reasoning via Translation-Reasoning Integrated Training

author.name: Junxiao Liu, Zhijun Wang, Yixiao Li, Zhejian Lai, Liqian Huang, Xin Huang, Xue Han, Junlan Feng, Shujian Huang

entry.summary: Proposes TRIT, a self-improving framework that integrates translation training into multilingual reasoning to enhance both question understanding and response generation without external feedback.

entry.title: Weaver: End-to-End Agentic System Training for Video Interleaved Reasoning

author.name: Yudi Shi, Shangzhe Di, Qirui Chen, Qinian Wang, Jiayin Cai, Xiaolong Jiang, Yao Hu, Weidi Xie

entry.summary: Introduces Weaver, an end-to-end trainable multimodal reasoning agentic system for video that enables dynamic tool invocation during reasoning to progressively acquire visual cues, constructing authentic multimodal reasoning chains.

entry.title: Visuo-Tactile World Models

author.name: Carolina Higuera, Sergio Arnaud, Byron Boots, Mustafa Mukadam, Francois Robert Hogan, Franziska Meier

entry.summary: Introduces Visuo-Tactile World Models (VT-WM) that combine vision and tactile sensing to better model contact-rich manipulation tasks, achieving 33% better object permanence and 29% better physics compliance compared to vision-only models, with improved downstream policy performance.

entry.title: ASA: Activation Steering for Tool-Calling Domain Adaptation

author.name: Youjin Wang, Run Zhou, Rong Fu, Shuaishuai Cao, Hongwei Zeng, Jiaxuan Lu, Sicheng Fan, Jiaqiao Zhao, Liangming Pan

entry.summary: Proposes Activation Steering Adapter (ASA), a training-free, inference-time mechanism for domain adaptation of LLM tool-calling capabilities. Uses intermediate activations to produce adaptive control for domain alignment, achieving LoRA-comparable results without training.

entry.title: PATHWAYS: Evaluating Investigation and Context Discovery in AI Web Agents

author.name: Shifat E. Arman, Syed Nazmus Sakib, Tapodhir Karmakar Taton, Nafiul Haque, Shahrear Bin Amin

entry.summary: Introduces PATHWAYS benchmark of 250 multi-step web tasks testing whether agents can discover hidden contextual information. Finds agents frequently hallucinate investigative reasoning and fail to integrate discovered context.

entry.title: Determining Energy Efficiency Sweet Spots in Production LLM Inference

author.name: Hiari Pizzini Cavagna, Andrea Proia, Giacomo Madella, Giovanni B. Esposito, Francesco Antici, Daniele Cesarini, Zeynep Kiziltan, Andrea Bartolini

entry.summary: Proposes an analytical model for LLM inference energy efficiency based on Transformer computational and memory-access complexity, revealing non-linear energy efficiency regimes dependent on input/output lengths.

entry.title: EntRGi: Entropy Aware Reward Guidance for Diffusion Language Models

author.name: Atula Tejaswi, Litu Rout, Constantine Caramanis, Sanjay Shakkottai, Sujay Sanghavi

entry.summary: Proposes EntRGi, an entropy-aware reward guidance method for discrete diffusion language models. Addresses the challenge that discrete tokens can't be directly differentiated through, showing downsides of continuous relaxation and straight-through estimators.

entry.title: CoSA: Compressed Sensing-Based Adaptation of Large Language Models

author.name: Songtao Wei, Yi Li, Bohan Zhang, Zhichun Guo, Ying Huang, Yuede Ji, Miao Yin, Guanpeng Li, Bingzhe Li

entry.summary: Proposes CoSA, a PEFT method based on compressed sensing theory that expresses weight updates through fixed random projection matrices rather than low-rank decomposition. Provides theoretical guarantees and aims to overcome expressivity limitations of LoRA.

entry.title: BLITZRANK: Principled Zero-shot Ranking Agents with Tournament Graphs

author.name: Sheshansh Agrawal, Thien Hang Nguyen, Douwe Kiela

entry.summary: Introduces BLITZRANK, a tournament graph framework for zero-shot LLM reranking that exploits the fact each k-document comparison reveals k-choose-2 pairwise preferences, using transitive closure to obtain additional orderings without model calls.

entry.title: Once Correct, Still Wrong: Counterfactual Hallucination in Multilingual Vision-Language Models

author.name: Basel Mousi, Fahim Dalvi, Shammur Chowdhury, Firoj Alam, Nadir Durrani

entry.summary: Introduces M2CQA benchmark for measuring counterfactual hallucination in VLMs across MENA cultural contexts. Proposes CFHR metric measuring acceptance of false statements conditioned on correctly answering true ones.

entry.title: KV-CoRE: Benchmarking Data-Dependent Low-Rank Compressibility of KV-Caches in LLMs

author.name: Jian Chen, Zhuoran Wang, Jiayu Qin, Ming Li, Meng Wang, Changyou Chen, Yin Chen, Qizhen Weng, Yirui Liu

entry.summary: Introduces KV-CoRE, an SVD-based method for quantifying data-dependent low-rank compressibility of KV-caches across layers and datasets. Provides gradient-free, incremental evaluation methodology.

entry.title: Beyond Cosine Similarity

author.name: Xinbo Ai

entry.summary: Proposes 'recos', a new similarity metric derived from a tighter upper bound than Cauchy-Schwarz for dot products. Relaxes perfect similarity from linear dependence to ordinal concordance, potentially capturing nonlinear semantic relationships.

entry.title: ProAct: Agentic Lookahead in Interactive Environments

author.name: Yangbin Yu, Mingyu Yang, Junyou Li, Yiming Gao, Feiyu Liu, Yijun Yang, Zichuan Lin, Jiafei Lyu, Yicheng Liu, Zhicong Lu, Deheng Ye, Jie Jiang

entry.summary: Proposes ProAct, a framework for LLM agent lookahead in interactive environments via two-stage training: distilling environment-based search into causal reasoning chains, then refining with Monte-Carlo Critic reinforcement learning.

entry.title: ALIVE: Awakening LLM Reasoning via Adversarial Learning and Instructive Verbal Evaluation

author.name: Yiwen Duan, Jing Ye, Xinpei Zhao

entry.summary: Introduces ALIVE, an adversarial learning framework for LLM reasoning that replaces scalar rewards with verbal evaluation. Uses cognitive synergy principles to unify problem solving and evaluation in a hands-free alignment approach.

entry.title: SDFP: Speculative Decoding with FIT-Pruned Models for Training-Free and Plug-and-Play LLM Acceleration

author.name: Hanyu Wei, Zunhai Su, Peng Lu, Chao Li, Spandan Tiwari, Ashish Sirasao, Yuhan Dong

entry.summary: Proposes SDFP, a training-free speculative decoding framework that creates draft models via Fisher Information Trace-based layer pruning of the target LLM, requiring no auxiliary training or optimization.

entry.title: Agent2Agent Threats in Safety-Critical LLM Assistants: A Human-Centric Taxonomy

author.name: Lukas Stappen, Ahmet Erkan Turan, Johann Hagerer, Georg Groh

entry.summary: Proposes a human-centric security taxonomy for agent-to-agent threats in safety-critical LLM assistants (e.g., vehicle systems), separating assets from attack vectors in the context of Google's A2A protocol.

entry.title: Momentum Attention: The Physics of In-Context Learning and Spectral Forensics for Mechanistic Interpretability

author.name: Kingsuk Maitra

entry.summary: Introduces 'Momentum Attention,' a physics-inspired augmentation to transformer attention using symplectic mechanics. Identifies a fundamental Symplectic-Filter Duality showing that injecting kinematic momentum is equivalent to high-pass filtering, enabling single-layer induction head formation.

entry.title: Near-Optimal Dynamic Matching via Coarsening with Application to Heart Transplantation

author.name: Itai Zilberstein, Ioannis Anagnostides, Zachary W. Sollie, Arman Kilic, Tuomas Sandholm

entry.summary: Develops near-optimal online matching algorithms using a coarsening approach where offline nodes are aggregated into capacitated clusters. Applied to heart transplant allocation with theoretical guarantees that closely match the omniscient benchmark.

entry.title: Do Vision-Language Models Respect Contextual Integrity in Location Disclosure?

author.name: Ruixin Yang, Ethan Mendes, Arthur Wang, James Hays, Sauvik Das, Wei Xu, Alan Ritter

entry.summary: Studies whether VLMs respect contextual integrity in location disclosure, examining when geolocation from images is appropriate vs. privacy-violating. Proposes that VLMs should reason about context to determine appropriate disclosure levels rather than applying blanket restrictions.

entry.title: VISTA: Enhancing Visual Conditioning via Track-Following Preference Optimization in Vision-Language-Action Models

author.name: Yiye Chen, Yanan Jian, Xiaoyi Dong, Shuxin Cao, Jing Wu, Patricio Vela, Benjamin E. Lundell, Dongdong Chen

entry.summary: Proposes VISTA, a training framework that strengthens visual conditioning in Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models through track-following preference optimization. Shows that successful robot rollouts exhibit stronger visual dependence than failed ones.

entry.title: Rethinking Rubric Generation for Improving LLM Judge and Reward Modeling for Open-ended Tasks

author.name: William F. Shen, Xinchi Qiu, Chenxi Whitehouse, Lisa Alazraki, Shashwat Goel, Francesco Barbieri, Timon Willi, Akhil Mathur, Ilias Leontiadis

entry.summary: Proposes RRD, a framework for rubric refinement that recursively decomposes and filters rubric criteria for LLM-as-judge evaluation and reinforcement fine-tuning. Addresses issues of coverage gaps, conflated dimensions, and correlated criteria in generated rubrics.

entry.title: Towards Worst-Case Guarantees with Scale-Aware Interpretability

author.name: Lauren Greenspan, David Berman, Aryeh Brill, Ro Jefferson, Artemy Kolchinsky, Jennifer Lin, Andrew Mack, Anindita Maiti, Fernando E. Rosas, Alexander Stapleton, Lucas Teixeira, Dmitry Vaintrob

entry.summary: Proposes using renormalization group (RG) methods from physics for scale-aware interpretability of neural networks, aiming to provide worst-case guarantees by tracking how features compose across resolutions. Frames this as a research agenda for AI safety.

entry.title: ZeroS: Zero-Sum Linear Attention for Efficient Transformers

author.name: Jiecheng Lu, Xu Han, Yan Sun, Viresh Pati, Yubin Kim, Siddhartha Somani, Shihao Yang

entry.summary: Proposes Zero-Sum Linear Attention (ZeroS), which removes the constant zero-order term from linear attention and reweights zero-sum softmax residuals. Enables both positive and negative attention weights for contrastive operations while maintaining O(N) complexity.

entry.title: FlashBlock: Attention Caching for Efficient Long-Context Block Diffusion

author.name: Zhuokun Chen, Jianfei Cai, Bohan Zhuang

entry.summary: Proposes FlashBlock, exploiting cross-step redundancy of attention in block diffusion by caching attention outputs from tokens outside the current block across diffusion steps. Addresses attention bottleneck in long-context block diffusion for text and video generation.

entry.title: Spider-Sense: Intrinsic Risk Sensing for Efficient Agent Defense with Hierarchical Adaptive Screening

author.name: Zhenxiong Yu, Zhi Yang, Zhiheng Jin, Shuhe Wang, Heng Zhang, Yanlin Fei, Lingfeng Zeng, Fangqi Lou, Shuo Zhang, Tu Hu, Jingping Liu, Rongze Chen, Xingyu Zhu, Kunyi Wang, Chaofa Yuan, Xin Guo, Zhaowei Liu, Feipeng Zhang, Jie Huang, Huacan Wang, Ronghao Chen, Liwen Zhang

entry.summary: Proposes Spider-Sense, an event-driven defense framework for LLM agents using Intrinsic Risk Sensing (IRS) that triggers defenses only upon risk perception rather than at predefined stages. Uses hierarchical adaptive screening for efficient defense.

entry.title: Structured Context Engineering for File-Native Agentic Systems: Evaluating Schema Accuracy, Format Effectiveness, and Multi-File Navigation at Scale

author.name: Damon McMillan

entry.summary: Presents a large-scale empirical study (9,649 experiments across 11 models and 4 formats) on how to structure context for LLM agents, using SQL generation as a proxy. Finds that optimal context format is model-dependent and that file-based retrieval helps frontier models but not necessarily open-source ones.

entry.title: DECO: Decoupled Multimodal Diffusion Transformer for Bimanual Dexterous Manipulation with a Plugin Tactile Adapter

author.name: Xukun Li, Yu Sun, Lei Zhang, Bosheng Huang, Yibo Peng, Yuan Meng, Haojun Jiang, Shaoxuan Xie, Guacai Yao, Alois Knoll, Zhenshan Bing, Xinlong Wang, Zhenguo Sun

entry.summary: Presents DECO, a Diffusion Transformer-based policy for bimanual dexterous manipulation with a plugin tactile adapter, along with DECO-50, a large dataset of 50+ hours covering 28 sub-tasks with tactile sensing.

entry.title: Variational Speculative Decoding: Rethinking Draft Training from Token Likelihood to Sequence Acceptance

author.name: Xiandong Zou, Jianshu Li, Jing Huang, Pan Zhou

entry.summary: Proposes Variational Speculative Decoding (VSD), formulating draft model training as variational inference over latent draft paths, maximizing marginal probability of target-model acceptance rather than single greedy trajectories.

entry.title: FHAIM: Fully Homomorphic AIM For Private Synthetic Data Generation

author.name: Mayank Kumar, Qian Lou, Paulo Barreto, Martine De Cock, Sikha Pentyala

entry.summary: Proposes FHAIM, the first fully homomorphic encryption framework for training synthetic data generators on encrypted tabular data, adapting the AIM algorithm for FHE computation.

entry.title: EuroLLM-22B: Technical Report

author.name: Miguel Moura Ramos, Duarte M. Alves, Hippolyte Gisserot-Boukhlef, Jo\~ao Alves, Pedro Henrique Martins, Patrick Fernandes, Jos\'e Pombal, Nuno M. Guerreiro, Ricardo Rei, Nicolas Boizard, Amin Farajian, Mateusz Klimaszewski, Jos\'e G. C. de Souza, Barry Haddow, Fran\c{c}ois Yvon, Pierre Colombo, Alexandra Birch, Andr\'e F. T. Martins

entry.summary: Presents EuroLLM-22B, a multilingual LLM trained from scratch covering all 24 EU languages plus 11 additional languages, with competitive performance on multilingual reasoning, instruction following, and translation benchmarks.

entry.title: Better Source, Better Flow: Learning Condition-Dependent Source Distribution for Flow Matching

author.name: Junwan Kim, Jiho Park, Seonghu Jeon, Seungryong Kim

entry.summary: Proposes learning condition-dependent source distributions for flow matching in text-to-image generation, showing that optimizing the source distribution (rather than defaulting to Gaussian) improves generation quality at scale.

entry.title: Correctness-Optimized Residual Activation Lens (CORAL): Transferrable and Calibration-Aware Inference-Time Steering

author.name: Miranda Muqing Miao, Young-Min Cho, Lyle Ungar

entry.summary: Introduces CORAL, a regularized inference-time steering method using weight-decay MLP probes on internal activations to improve both accuracy (10%) and calibration (50% ECE reduction) across 7B parameter models.

entry.title: Simulated Adoption: Decoupling Magnitude and Direction in LLM In-Context Conflict Resolution

author.name: Long Zhang, Fangwei Lin

entry.summary: Analyzes how LLMs resolve in-context knowledge conflicts mechanistically, decomposing residual stream updates into radial (norm) and angular (cosine) components across multiple models, rejecting universal suppression hypotheses.

entry.title: Imposing Boundary Conditions on Neural Operators via Learned Function Extensions

author.name: Sepehr Mousavi, Siddhartha Mishra, Laura De Lorenzis

entry.summary: Proposes a framework for imposing boundary conditions on neural operators for PDEs by learning function extensions that map boundary data to latent pseudo-extensions over the full spatial domain. Enables standard operator learning architectures to handle complex non-homogeneous BCs.

entry.title: Causal Representation Meets Stochastic Modeling under Generic Geometry

author.name: Jiaxu Ren, Yixin Wang, Biwei Huang

entry.summary: Develops identifiable causal representation learning for continuous-time stochastic processes under generic geometry, extending prior work from i.i.d./discrete-time settings to multivariate point processes and other continuous-time domains.

entry.title: SpectraKAN: Conditioning Spectral Operators

author.name: Chun-Wun Cheng, Carola-Bibiane Sch\"onlieb, Angelica I. Aviles-Rivero
